text_image_relationship.layout_style: Left page: single column of text at top, below a figurative scene occupying the lower two-thirds of the page; right page: full-page map-like illustration with toponyms integrated into the pictorial field. The visual hierarchy favors the right-hand cartographic image, with the narrative scene on the left subordinate. Generous white-space margins frame both sections; the central gutter sharply divides narrative and cartographic content.

text_content.script_style: Gothic cursive documentary hand with fluid strokes, extensive use of standard medieval abbreviations and ligatures, executed by a professional scribe.

color_scheme.color_usage: Red used for garments and map symbols; green reserved for foliage and map ground; ochre for terrain; black for defining outlines and text. Colors applied in flat, even washes with minimal shading. The palette remains well-preserved with stable pigments and only slight fading of ochre tones.

features: Central grouping of figures on left page
Full-page cartographic mass on right page
Overlap of figures to suggest proximity
Trees at page margins providing vertical framing

decorative_elements: Map symbols (clustered huts and red vegetation marks)

drawing_technique.line_style: Bold black ink outlines with uniform line weight, quill pen work
drawing_technique.shading_method: None; volume implied purely by outline and flat color fields
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat, hierarchical scaling; no attempt at linear perspective, depth implied by overlapping elements

content_theme.scene_description: A single narrative scene on the left page depicts four secular figures standing on ochre ground beneath two stylized trees. The principal figure, at right, holds a long staff topped by a Latin cross and wears a patterned tunic of vermilion and ochre over red hose and pointed shoes. Three attendants to his left wear varied hats (a red chaperon, a turned-up hood, and a simple cap) and plain tunics in muted green and brown; two gesture toward the cross-bearer, one listens with folded arms. The figures overlap slightly to indicate spatial grouping. Costumes include patterned wool tunics and linen hose, with visible seams and simple decorative dagging. No architectural setting is present. The plain white ground of the background focuses attention on interpersonal exchange. The group is centrally placed beneath the caption, creating a clear hierarchical emphasis on their meeting.

secular: Principal figure holding cross staff, wearing patterned tunic and red hose, pointed shoes
Attendant in red chaperon and brown tunic gesturing toward principal
Attendant in turned-up hood and green tunic listening with arms crossed
Attendant in simple cap and ochre tunic pointing outward

objects: tall wooden staff topped by Latin cross
natural: Two stylized trees with round green crowns and red fruit

technical_features.material: Smooth calf vellum, uniform thickness, professionally prepared and ruled with plummet lines faintly visible
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall good: pigments remain vivid with minimal flaking, slight fading of ochre; parchment shows minor cockling at edges; later library stamp on right page
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in brown ink beneath figures
Plummet ruling grid faintly evident in margins
Flat application of pigment with sharp outlines
No raised gesso or metal leaf present

functional_analysis.primary_function: Historical record (itinerarium or chronicle combining narrative and cartographic elements)
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Monastic or clerical readers compiling or consulting a regional chronicle for administrative or historiographical use

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This two-page spread exemplifies the late medieval practice of combining narrative episodes with rudimentary cartography in itineraries or regional chronicles. Produced on fine calf vellum and penned in a professional Gothic cursive hand, the manuscript likely originated in a northern Italian or southern German workshop c. 1400–1450. The historian’s concern for accuracy is evident in the map-like right page, where clusters of huts and schematic vegetation marks denote key waystations, while the left page captures a diplomatic encounter in concise visual form. The limited palette of vermilion, verdigris, ochre, and black reflects economical pigment use, yet the flat color fields and crisp outlines convey immediacy. Iconographically, the cross-topped staff signals ecclesiastical or crusading authority, and the attendants’ gestures emphasize negotiation. The absence of architectural framing focuses attention on interpersonal dynamics rather than grand settings. Comparatively, this iconography aligns with other itineraria such as the Liber de itinere terrae sanctae, though its regional emphasis and documentary script distinguish it as a local record. The workshop’s sparing use of decorative elements and reliance on clear, schematic representation point to a functional codicological tradition rather than a luxury commission. This spread therefore occupies a liminal space between scholarly chronicle and pictorial map, illustrating medieval efforts to merge text, image, and geography in service of historical memory.
